questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the role of telomerase in cellular ageing?

choices.text: Telomerase accelerates ageing by reducing the length of telomeres with each cell division
Telomerase maintains the constant telomere length in somatic cells throughout their lifespan.
Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cell's lifespan.
Telomerase is a Ribozyme delaying cell aging.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cells' lifespan.

Explanation:

Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cells' lifespan.

Telomere: It is the sequence present on the terminal of chromosomes. Ageing is due to the shortening of telomeres as the person grows.

Telomerase, also known as the immortality gene, is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase enzyme that adds DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, preventing telomere shortening during cell division.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the concept of the Hayflick Limit?

choices.text: The ageing of cells is not determined by telomere length.
It refers to the age at which cells cease all metabolic activities and undergo apoptosis.
A cell typically undergoes 20-40 cell divisions before reaching senescence.
It represents the average number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It represents the maximum number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.

Explanation: 

The Hayflick limit or Hayflick’s phenomenon represents the number of cell divisions a cell undergoes before reaching its replicative senescence or ageing.

  • Somatic cells typically undergo around 60-100 divisions before entering a state of replicative senescence.
  • Cells start to show signs of ageing after a finite number of divisions due to factors like telomere shortening and changes in gene expression.

questions.text: How do “Sirtuins” contribute to cellular ageing?

choices.text: By accelerating telomere shortening.
By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.
By functioning as histone acetyltransferases, promoting chromatin condensation.
By decreasing insulin sensitivity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.

Explanation:

Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases produced by SIRT genes (SIRT1-7) that play a key role in DNA repair mechanisms and are involved in maintaining genomic stability

Functions/benefits of sirtuins:

  • Anti-ageing
    • Prevents telomerase from shortening (Option A ruled out)
  • Cell repair 
  • Increases the insulin sensitivity of tissues: Beneficial for DM patients and slows down ageing. (Option D ruled out)

Sirtuins are histone deacetylases (Option C ruled out)

Sirtuins increase insulin sensitivity

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral cataracts, short stature, premature greying and loss of hair, and skin changes. He also reports joint stiffness and pain, as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the patient appears older than his stated age, with characteristic "bird-like" facies and a high-pitched voice. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with his presentation?

choices.text: Hutchinson-Gilford Syndrome
Werner syndrome
Wermer syndrome
Cockayne Syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Werner syndrome

Explanation:

The clinical presentation points towards Werner syndrome, also known as Adult Progeria Syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by premature ageing features that typically manifest in adulthood. It is associated with a DNA helicase defect.

Hutchinson-Gilford Syndrome (Option A): It is a rare genetic progeroid syndrome characterized by severe premature ageing features that begin in childhood. It is a Laminopathy due to a Lamin-A (LMNA) gene mutation.

Wermer Syndrome (Option C): Wermer Syndrome is for as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1).

Cockayne Syndrome (Option D): It is also a rare autosomal recessive progeroid syndrome. However, it typically presents in childhood. ERCC gene defect.

questions.text: Which cellular process is primarily responsible for the degradation and recycling of unnecessary or dysfunctional cellular components?

choices.text: Autophagy
Necrosis
Apoptosis
Pyroptosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autophagy

Explanation:

Autophagy (aka cell cannibalism) is a cellular process by which a cell eats its own contents and plays a critical role in maintaining cellular homeostasis, responding to stressors such as nutrient deprivation, and eliminating potentially harmful cellular materials.

  • Autophagy has 4 types:
    • Macro-autophagy: Eats substrate by forming a membrane around it (Autophagosome)
    • Micro-autophagy: Eats substrate by endocytosis
    • Chaperone-mediated autophagy
    • Mitophagy: Mitochondria are eaten
  • Marker of autophagy: LC3
  • Most important gene for autophagy: ATG1 gene

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) targets misfolded proteins for degradation?

choices.text: Direct uptake by lysosomes via endocytosis
Activation of mTOR leading to inhibition of ULK1 complex
Selective degradation of damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria
Binding of chaperones to misfolded proteins, followed by lysosomal entry via LAMP2A for autophagy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Binding of chaperones to misfolded proteins, followed by lysosomal entry via LAMP2A for autophagy

Explanation:

In chaperone-mediated autophagy, chaperone proteins (Eg, Heat shock proteins) recognize and bind to specific protein substrates that are misfolded or damaged. The chaperone-substrate complex then interacts with the lysosomal-associated membrane protein LAMP2A, facilitating the substrate protein's translocation into the lysosome for degradation.

Direct uptake by lysosomes via endocytosis (Option A) is mechanism is observed in Microautophagy.

Inhibition of mTOR leading to activation of ULK1 complex (Option B) is seen in Macroautophagy.

Selective degradation of damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria (Option C) is seen in Mitophagy.

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is associated with autophagy?

choices.text: Annexin A1
Annexin V
Beclin 1
LC3

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) LC3

Explanation:

  • LC3, or Microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3, is a reliable marker of autophagy.
  • Most important gene for autophagy: ATG1 gene

Annexin A1 (Option A): Annexin A1 is a marker of hairy cell leukaemia.

Annexin 5 (Option B): Marker of apoptosis

Beclin 1 (Option C): Beclin-1 is not a direct marker of autophagy but plays a crucial role in initiating autophagy

questions.text: Which statement accurately distinguishes between hypertrophy and hyperplasia?

choices.text: Hypertrophy involves an increase in cell number, while hyperplasia involves an increase in cell size.
Hypertrophy increases tissue mass, while hyperplasia maintains tissue mass.
Hypertrophy is irreversible, while hyperplasia is reversible.
Hypertrophy results from increased cellular protein production, while hyperplasia involves growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypertrophy results from increased cellular protein production, while hyperplasia involves growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.

Explanation:

Hypertrophy results from increased cellular protein production, while hyperplasia involves growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.

Hypertrophy Hyperplasia
  • Hypertrophy is characterized by increased cellular protein (GATA4, NFAT, MEF2) production, which leads to the enlargement of cells and tissues due to an increase in cell size.
  • An increase in cellular proteins occurs either through enhanced central dogma processes (transcription and translation) or through an increase of transcription factors.
  • Hyperplasia is described as the result of growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.
  • In hyperplasia, the number of cells within an organ or tissue increases.

 

  • Hypertrophy involves an increase in cell size, while hyperplasia involves an increase in cell number. (Option A ruled out)
  • Both hypertrophy and hyperplasia increase tissue mass. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hypertrophy can be reversible. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding for the past six months. She reports experiencing prolonged periods lasting more than ten days with excessive bleeding, abdominal discomfort, and pelvic pain during her menstrual cycle. On further evaluation, transvaginal ultrasound reveals thickening of the endometrial lining. Endometrial biopsy confirms the presence of abnormal glandular proliferation without cytologic atypia. Which of the following best describes the cellular adaptation observed in this clinical scenario?

choices.text: Physiological hypertrophy
Pathological hypertrophy
Physiological hyperplasia
Pathological hyperplasia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pathological hyperplasia

Explanation:

This is a case of endometrial hyperplasia, a pathological hyperplasia.

 

Definition

Examples

Physiological hypertrophy
(Option A)

Increase in the size of cells or organs.
  • Uterine hypertrophy during pregnancy due to estrogenic hormone signalling.

Pathological hypertrophy
(Option B)

Cell enlargement occurs in response to increased workload or stress
  • Heart enlargement from hypertension or valvular disease.

Physiological hyperplasia
(Option C)

An increase in the number of cells in response to hormonal or growth factor stimulation.
  • Breast glandular epithelium proliferation during puberty or pregnancy.

Pathological hyperplasia
(Option D)

Occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue due to excessive or inappropriate hormonal or growth factor stimulation
  • Endometrial hyperplasia due to disturbance in estrogen-progesterone balance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of hypertrophy is inaccurate?

choices.text: Activation of G-protein-coupled receptor-initiated pathways
Stimulation of growth factor production such as TGF-β and IGF1
Inhibition of transcription factors like GATA4, MEF2, NFAT
Activation of downstream pathways including the PI3K/AKT pathway

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibition of transcription factors like GATA4, MEF2, NFAT

Explanation:

Hypertrophy actually involves the activation (not inhibition) of transcription factors such as GATA4, NFAT, and MEF2.

  • They enhance the expression of genes encoding muscle proteins, promoting cellular growth and hypertrophy.
  • When transcription factors will increase:
    • More DNA will be converted to RNA, which will create more proteins, leading to an increase in cell size (hypertrophy).

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of physiological atrophy?

choices.text: Testicular atrophy due to hypogonadism
Intestinal villi atrophy in malabsorption syndromes
Reduction in thymus gland size during ageing
Brain atrophy in neurodegenerative diseases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reduction in thymus gland size during ageing

Explanation:

Reduction in thymus gland size during ageing is an example of physiological atrophy.

Physiological atrophy refers to the normal, programmed decrease in the size or mass of tissues, organs, or structures in the body.

  • The thymus gland, which is involved in the development of the immune system, tends to decrease in size and activity with age, which is an example of physiological atrophy.

Pathological atrophy, on the other hand, refers to the abnormal decrease in the size or mass of tissues, organs, or structures due to disease, injury, or other abnormal conditions.

  • Testicular atrophy, intestinal atrophy and brain atrophy  are examples of pathological atrophy. (Options A, B, D ruled out)

questions.text: Which type of atrophy is observed in a patient with smaller and weaker muscles who is bedridden for several weeks?

choices.text: Disuse atrophy
Neurogenic atrophy
Endocrine atrophy
Senile atrophy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Disuse atrophy

Explanation:

Disuse atrophy is seen in a patient with smaller, weaker muscles after being bedridden for several weeks.

  • During prolonged periods of immobility, such as extended bed rest, the muscles experience decreased mechanical loading and activity.
  • This lack of stimulation decreases muscle protein synthesis and increases protein breakdown, resulting in muscle wasting and weakness.

Neurogenic atrophy (Option B): Atrophy due to hampered nerve supply. E.g.- In polio patients, the muscle will become immobile, leading to neurogenic atrophy.

Endocrine atrophy (Option C): Atrophy due to a decrease in hormones. E.g. - A decrease in the level of estrogens leading to endometrial atrophy, which is seen in postmenopausal women.

Senile atrophy (Option D): Seen in old age and in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: Which type of metaplasia characterizes the histological changes observed in Barrett's oesophagus?

choices.text: Transformation of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium
Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells
Conversion of glandular epithelium to squamous epithelium
Substitution of mesenchymal cells with epithelial cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells

Explanation:

  • Barrett's oesophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower oesophagus with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells. (Goblet cells contain acidic mucin staining positive with alcian blue, which helps to differentiate from intestinal epithelium)
  • This metaplastic change is considered an adaptive response to chronic exposure to gastric acid and bile reflux in the setting of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding metaplasia is true?

choices.text: Metaplasia refers to the abnormal growth of cells, often leading to cancer.
It is a reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type.
Metaplasia is always a pathological process and never occurs in response to normal physiological stimuli.
Metaplasia is characterized by the replacement of differentiated cells with undifferentiated stem cells.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is a reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type

Explanation:

Metaplasia is a reversible process in which one adult cell type is replaced by another, typically in response to chronic irritation or inflammation. Either 1 epithelium can change into another or 1 mesenchymal cell can change into another mesenchymal cell

  • In metaplasia, normal cells are involved. If cells are abnormal, then it is Dysplasia (Option A ruled out)
  • Metaplasia can sometimes occur in response to normal physiological stimuli (Option C ruled out)
  • In metaplasis, the programming of stem cells is changing, because of which previous epithelium is replaced by new epithelium (Option D ruled out)
